episodeTitle: Back to the Present! Hordy Makes a Move!
description: After witnessing the tragic aftermath of Queen Otohime's assassination and Hody Jones' manipulation of the truth, the story returns to the present. Nami forgives Jinbe for his connection to Arlong, and Hody Jones broadcasts his plan to take over Fish-Man Island.

events.title: Hody Jones Frames Human for Otohime's Murder
events.description: In a flashback, Hody Jones presents the body of a human pirate to the grieving citizens of Fish-Man Island, claiming this human killed Queen Otohime. Despite Jinbe's orders to hide the body, Hody deliberately exposes it to incite anti-human sentiment and undermine Otohime's dream of coexistence.
events.significance: This reveals Hody's calculated manipulation and the foundation of his hatred campaign against humans. It shows how he weaponized Otohime's death to further his own extremist agenda, planting the seeds for his eventual takeover attempt of Fish-Man Island.

quotes.text: This is the human who killed Queen Otohime!
quotes.speaker: Hody Jones
quotes.context: Hody presenting the framed human pirate to incite hatred

events.title: Neptune's Grief and Moral Struggle
events.description: King Neptune locks himself in Hard-Shell Tower, consumed by grief and rage over Otohime's death. He confesses to his ministers that he would have killed the shooter even if unarmed, but realizes Otohime would not have wanted that. The ministers stay with him to ensure he calms down before emerging.
events.significance: This moment demonstrates Neptune's internal conflict between his desire for vengeance and his commitment to his wife's ideals of peace and forgiveness. It shows the emotional toll of Otohime's assassination on those closest to her and highlights the difficulty of maintaining her peaceful vision in the face of such tragedy.

quotes.text: I would have killed the shooter even if he was unarmed... But Otohime would not want that.
quotes.speaker: King Neptune
quotes.context: Neptune reflecting on his rage and Otohime's values

events.title: Nami Forgives Jinbe
events.description: After hearing the full story of Fish-Man Island's history and Jinbe's connection to Arlong, Jinbe asks Nami for forgiveness and offers to accept any punishment. Nami responds that she resents only Arlong, not fish-men as a whole, and that she is happy with who she has become. She notes that through her horrible experience came new friends, and she harbors no resentment toward fish-men.
events.significance: This is a pivotal character development moment for Nami, showing her emotional maturity and ability to separate individual actions from collective blame. It demonstrates her growth from a traumatized victim to someone who can forgive and move forward. The scene also deeply impacts Jinbe and Hatchan, who are moved to tears by her compassion.

quotes.text: I resent only Arlong, not any other fish-man. I'm happy as I am now.
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami forgiving Jinbe and refusing to blame all fish-men for Arlong's actions

quotes.text: I will take any punishment you wish.
quotes.speaker: Jinbe

events.title: Sanji Kicks Luffy for Sleeping
events.description: Sanji kicks Luffy in the face for sleeping through Jinbe's entire emotional story about Fish-Man Island's tragic history. The moment provides comic relief after the heavy backstory revelations.
events.significance: This humorous moment demonstrates Luffy's characteristic obliviousness and Sanji's frustration, while also showing the Straw Hats' crew dynamics. Despite the serious nature of the story being told, it reinforces that Luffy operates on his own wavelength and doesn't need to hear tragic histories to judge people - he judges them by their current actions.

events.title: Hatchan Explains Hody's Hatred
events.description: Hatchan explains that Hody Jones' hatred toward humans is even greater than Arlong's was. He reveals that this year is the year of the World Summit, and King Neptune was planning to attend to spread news of Fish-Man Island's desire for surface integration. Hatchan warns that Hody plans to take Neptune's place and do something far worse.
events.significance: This establishes Hody Jones as a more extreme threat than even Arlong, escalating the stakes for the arc. It also connects Fish-Man Island's story to the larger One Piece world through the World Summit, showing how local conflicts intersect with global politics. The revelation sets up Hody's true motivations and the scope of his ambitions.

quotes.text: Hody's hatred towards humans is even greater than Arlong's.
quotes.speaker: Hatchan
quotes.context: Warning the Straw Hats about the severity of Hody's extremism

events.title: Hody Jones' Island-Wide Broadcast Begins
events.description: A large mobile visual Den Den Mushi appears before the Straw Hats and across all of Fish-Man Island. Hody Jones begins his broadcast, announcing the New Fish-Man Pirates' takeover of the entire island to all its citizens. The broadcast marks the beginning of his coup.
events.significance: This is the turning point of the Fish-Man Island Arc, where Hody's plans move from conspiracy to open revolution. The public broadcast demonstrates his confidence and marks the official start of his attempt to overthrow the Ryugu Kingdom. It sets up the major conflict that will dominate the remainder of the arc.

quotes.text: I resent only Arlong, not any other fish-man. I'm happy as I am now.
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Forgiving Jinbe and refusing to blame all fish-men

quotes.text: I would have killed the shooter even if he was unarmed... But Otohime would not want that.
quotes.speaker: King Neptune
quotes.context: Struggling with grief and vengeance versus peace

quotes.text: Hody's hatred towards humans is even greater than Arlong's.
quotes.speaker: Hatchan

quotes.text: This is the human who killed Queen Otohime!
quotes.speaker: Hody Jones
quotes.context: Framing an innocent human for the assassination

themes.description: The episode explores the theme of forgiveness through Nami's decision to forgive Jinbe despite her traumatic past with Arlong. Her ability to separate individual guilt from collective blame demonstrates emotional maturity and the power of choosing compassion over hatred.
themes.symbolism: Nami's forgiveness represents the possibility of breaking cycles of hatred, contrasting with Hody's choice to perpetuate it.

themes.description: Hody Jones' manipulation of Otohime's death to incite anti-human sentiment demonstrates how hatred can be weaponized and perpetuated across generations, even in the absence of personal grievance.
themes.symbolism: The framed human pirate represents how easily truth can be twisted to serve extremist agendas.

themes.description: Neptune's internal struggle between his desire for revenge and his commitment to Otohime's ideals of peace illustrates the difficult choice between immediate emotional satisfaction and long-term moral principles.
themes.symbolism: Neptune's seclusion in Hard-Shell Tower represents the internal battle between primal rage and civilized restraint.

themes.description: Nami's forgiveness demonstrates how far she has come from the traumatized girl who suffered under Arlong's rule. Her ability to see beyond her own pain shows significant character development.
themes.symbolism: The contrast between young Nami crying for help and present Nami offering forgiveness marks her journey from victim to survivor.

characterSpotlights.development: Nami demonstrates remarkable emotional growth by forgiving Jinbe and refusing to blame all fish-men for Arlong's crimes. This moment shows her transformation from a victim seeking revenge to a mature person who can distinguish between individual responsibility and collective guilt.
keyActions: Listens to Jinbe's full story about Fish-Man Island history
Forgives Jinbe for his connection to Arlong
Affirms she is happy with who she has become
Makes Jinbe and Hatchan cry with her compassion
quotes: I resent only Arlong, not any other fish-man. I'm happy as I am now.

characterSpotlights.development: Jinbe's request for forgiveness shows his deep sense of responsibility for the pain Arlong caused, even though he wasn't directly involved. His emotional response to Nami's forgiveness demonstrates his honorable character and the weight he carried.
keyActions: Offers to accept any punishment she desires
quotes: I will take any punishment you wish.

characterSpotlights.development: Hody is revealed as a calculated manipulator who weaponized Otohime's death to further his extremist agenda. His public broadcast marks his transition from shadow conspirator to open revolutionary.
keyActions: Presents framed human pirate to incite hatred (flashback)
Defies Jinbe's orders to hide the body
quotes: This is the human who killed Queen Otohime!

characterSpotlights.development: Neptune's struggle between vengeance and his wife's ideals shows the human cost of maintaining peace in the face of tragedy. His character is tested as he must embody Otohime's vision despite his own pain.
keyActions: Locks himself in Hard-Shell Tower to avoid violent action
Confesses his desire for revenge to his ministers
Chooses to honor Otohime's peaceful vision despite his rage
quotes: I would have killed the shooter even if he was unarmed... But Otohime would not want that.

mangaDifferences.difference: In the manga, only the Minister of the Left was listening to Neptune's laments in the tower. In the anime, the Minister of the Right and some soldiers were also present.
Chopper asking Shirahoshi if she is friends with Sea Kings was omitted from the anime.
Shirahoshi holding Nami and Chopper in her hand was not shown in the anime like it was in the manga.
Neptune's emotional outburst in the tower was expanded with more elaborate dialogue in the anime.

trivia.fact: This episode adapts Chapter 627 pages 2-19, covering the aftermath of Otohime's assassination and transitioning back to the present timeline.
The episode aired in the US via simulcast one day before it aired in Japan due to time zone differences (May 12, 2012 US vs May 13, 2012 Japan).

This episode was praised in The One Piece Podcast's editorial 'Ten of the Most Well-Made One Piece Episodes' for its color palette and tender animation, particularly Neptune and Jinbe's crying scenes.

sources.title: Sam's Piece: Ten of the Most Well-Made 'One Piece' Episodes

trivia.fact: Nami's forgiveness scene is considered one of the highlights of the Fish-Man Island Arc, showcasing significant character development from her traumatic experiences in the Arlong Park arc.

sources.title: Fish-Man Island Arc - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The episode's screenplay was written by Hirohiko Kamisaka, with direction by Tetsuya Endō and animation direction by Takeo Ide.
